newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Koreans call for arrest of President's son.
newsitem.headline: S.Koreans call for arrest of President's son.

text.p: As state prosecutors prepared to arrest President Kim Young-sam's son for corruption on Thursday, most South Koreans showed little sympathy for the junior Kim and called for severe punishment.
They said President Kim, who jailed two of his predecessors as part of his anti-graft campaign, failed to cleanse his own administration and those around him.
"Kim Hyun-chul must pay for his sins, and must be judged by the law," said Kyung Yoon-duk, 43, who works at a food processing company.
Prosecutors say they have evidence that Kim Hyun-chul received billions of won (millions of dollars) from companies, some as kickbacks in return for influence-peddling.

"It's unfortunate that all our presidents are connected to corruption. I hope we elect a clean leader this year," said saleswoman Kim Chum-soo, referring to presidential elections to be held in December.
"After his term, it will be hard to avoid the criticism his predecessors received," Park Jung-ran, who runs a coffee shop, said of President Kim.

Many other Koreans said they felt betrayed by yet another sleaze scandal following the imprisonment of former presidents Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae-woo for raising hundreds of millions of dollars in slush funds while in office.
"This is too much. Even President Kim Young-sam's son is no different from Chun and Roh," said saleswoman Kim who added that most of her clients wanted to see the president's son behind bars.
"I have talked about Kim Hyun-chul when I met my customers, and most say he deserves to be arrested," she said.

President Kim came to office on an anti-graft ticket and his second son, who helped engineer his victory in the 1992 election campaign, now symbolised the failure of his administration's hopes of ending corruption.

Already, eleven people, including close aides to President Kim, ruling and opposition party lawmakers, a former cabinet minister, bankers and businessmen are on trial over a loans-for-kickbacks scandal surrounding failed Hanbo Steel Co.
But few Koreans said they would like to see President Kim stepping down over his son's wrongdoing.
"The country is going through hard times. I wouldn't want to see more chaos with the president resigning," said Lee Byung-ok, an 81-year-old pastor.
"The Korean people and politicians should use this opportunity to look back on themselves and make a fresh start."
"Kim Young-sam should use the rest of his term to straighten out the current mess," said coffeeshop owner Park.
Kwang Ee-do, 53, a chef at a Chinese restaurant, expressed scepticism that the expected arrest of Kim Hyun-chul would lead to a cleaner society.
